Award.AwardTitle: Multi-Physics Modeling and Experimental Characterization of Needleless Electrospinning for Scalable Nanofiber Production

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for research enabling the development of a fully three-dimensional multiphysics phase-field model and related experimentation for understanding of the electrohydrodynamic process of needleless electrospinning. Needleless electrospinning, based on free liquid-surface jetting, is a novel low-cost, top-down nanomanufacturing technique capable of continuous, scalable production of nanofibers of natural and synthetic polymers and polymer-derived carbon, ceramics, semiconductors, metals, metal oxides, etc. for broad applications in filtration, biomedical engineering, energy conversion and storage, nanocomposites, and so on. The developed computational model formulates a generalized free energy of an electrospinning system that is capable of uniformly treating the multiphysics, multiphase phenomenon of the process including multi-jet initiation, jet stretching, phase separation, drying, etc. The developed phase-field model can overcome the numerical difficulty in tracking the instantaneous profile of the liquid surface after multi-jetting and pore formation. Efficient semi-implicit spectral algorithm will be used for fast, robust numerical simulation. The model will determine several key parameters used in needleless electrospinning and be validated by controlled experimentation.

If successful, the results will establish solid theoretical foundation for needleless electrospinning and the predictive computational model will generate a wealth of fundamental knowledge for design, optimization and control of needleless electrospinning and other electrohydrodynamics-related devices (e.g., electrospray) for reliable, efficient, mass production. The results will benefit the computer-aided electrospinning engineering (CAEE) in education, research and industrial applications. The research provides a variety of opportunities for graduates and undergraduates, specially unrepresented minorities including Native American students and female students, to involve in the cutting-edge nanotechnology and computational materials science. The research will be demonstrated to K-12 students and students in the regional Native American tribal colleges. The results will be used for updating the relevant undergraduate and graduate curriculum materials and the development of a new cross-listed course at North Dakota State University.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF research award supported 4-year research on the multi-physics modeling and experimental characterization of needleless electrospinning for low-cost, continuous and scalable fabrication of nanofibers and related advanced applications of electrospun nanofibers, graduate and undergraduate student training, and outreaches.

The project supported (in full or in partial) 1 Ph.D. student, 5 M.S. students, and 5 undergraduate students (2 were female students), which has generated 1 Ph.D. dissertation and 2 M.S. theses at this time. To date, the research of the project has resulted in 2 international patents, 1 book chapter, 10 peer-referred journal papers, 1 education-oriented conference paper on hands-on nanomanufacturing machine design for undergraduate students, 1 technical conference paper, and 20 oral and post presentations in regional and national professional conferences. Some of the research methods and results of this project have been successfully integrated into the curriculum materials (in terms of featured course modules) of one graduate course and 4 undergraduate senior design projects (14 undergraduate senior students in Mechanical Engineering have been involved in these senior design projects, 4 of which were female students) on hands-on nanomanufacturing machine design and massive fabrication of nanofibers. Over 40 Native American (NA) tribal college and tribal high-school students and numerous prospective high-school students and their parents had visited the research laboratories of this project. In addition, two NA tribal college and high-school students were involved in the hands-on research of this project on nanofiber fabrication by electrospinning during a Summer Camp, which was also sponsored by the North Dakota Nurturing American Tribal Undergraduate Research and Education program (NATURE). This research project has also generated active research collaborations with researchers in several national and international universities in the field of nanofiber fabrication and related advanced nanofiber applications.

 

In the theoretical approach of the project, three-dimensional (3D) mechanism-based multi-physics models were formulated and implemented via effective numerical simulations for the purpose of understanding the coupling phenomenon of electrohydrodynamic jetting, surface dewetting and solvent evaporation (drying) in the multi-physics process of needleless electrospinning for low-cost, massive production of continuous nanofibers. These effective models are valuable to guide the quality-controllable, massive production of continuous nanofibers of synthetic and natural polymers and polymer-derived carbon, metals, semiconductors (including silicon), metal oxides, ceramics, etc. for broad advanced applications in nanocomposites, high-grade gas and liquid filtration, biomedical engineering, energy harvesting, conversion and storage devices, environmental protection, and other more. The multi-physics modeling and related effective numerical simulations will benefit the computer-aided electrospinning engineering (CAEE) in broader education, research and industrial applications of the scalable electrospinning technique and low-cost electrospun nanofibers.

 

In the experimental approach of the project, the jet initiation conditions of a particular wire-electrode-based needleless electrospinning setup were determined at varying polymer type, solute concentration, and electrode geometries, which can be used for developing and validating the theoretical models for model-based intelligent nanofiber manufacturing. In addition, an innovative dual-wire based needleless emulsion electrospinning method was formulated in this project, which first-time realized low-cost, continuous and scalable production of core-shell nanofibers and makes it possible for the industrial manufacturing and applications of large-quantity, continuous core-shell nanofibers in broader industrial and biomedical sectors, among others.

 

Moreover, the research of the project also experimentally explored several cutting-edge applications of electrospun nanofibers in high-performance electrodes of supercapacitors with high power and energy densities (energy storage), interface toughening and damage self-healing of advanced composite laminates (multi-scale hybrid self-healing polymer composites), as well as high-efficiency oil-water separation and water filtration (environmental protection). During this process, several rational synthesis routes of combining top-down electrospinning and bottom-up molecular/atomic self-assembly were formulated for first-time synthsis of several advanced hierarchally functionalized carbon nanofibers (CNFs) in the world. These advanced CNFs were demonstrated sucessfully for potential use as high-performance electrode materials in supercapacitors and pseduocapacitors such as graphene-beaded CNFs, ternary CNFs surface-grown with carbon-nanotubes (CNTs) and nanosized polyaninline, etc. 


Last Modified: 11/14/2016
Modified by: Xiangfa Wu
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This NSF research award supported 4-year research on the multi-physics modeling and experimental characterization of needleless electrospinning for low-cost, continuous and scalable fabrication of nanofibers and related advanced applications of electrospun nanofibers, graduate and undergraduate student training, and outreaches. The project supported (in full or in partial) 1 Ph.D. student, 5 M.S. students, and 5 undergraduate students (2 were female students), which has generated 1 Ph.D. dissertation and 2 M.S. theses at this time. To date, the research of the project has resulted in 2 international patents, 1 book chapter, 10 peer-referred journal papers, 1 education-oriented conference paper on hands-on nanomanufacturing machine design for undergraduate students, 1 technical conference paper, and 20 oral and post presentations in regional and national professional conferences. Some of the research methods and results of this project have been successfully integrated into the curriculum materials (in terms of featured course modules) of one graduate course and 4 undergraduate senior design projects (14 undergraduate senior students in Mechanical Engineering have been involved in these senior design projects, 4 of which were female students) on hands-on nanomanufacturing machine design and massive fabrication of nanofibers. Over 40 Native American (NA) tribal college and tribal high-school students and numerous prospective high-school students and their parents had visited the research laboratories of this project. In addition, two NA tribal college and high-school students were involved in the hands-on research of this project on nanofiber fabrication by electrospinning during a Summer Camp, which was also sponsored by the North Dakota Nurturing American Tribal Undergraduate Research and Education program (NATURE). This research project has also generated active research collaborations with researchers in several national and international universities in the field of nanofiber fabrication and related advanced nanofiber applications. In the theoretical approach of the project, three-dimensional (3D) mechanism-based multi-physics models were formulated and implemented via effective numerical simulations for the purpose of understanding the coupling phenomenon of electrohydrodynamic jetting, surface dewetting and solvent evaporation (drying) in the multi-physics process of needleless electrospinning for low-cost, massive production of continuous nanofibers. The multi-physics modeling and related effective numerical simulations will benefit the computer-aided electrospinning engineering (CAEE) in broader education, research and industrial applications of the scalable electrospinning technique and low-cost electrospun nanofibers. In the experimental approach of the project, the jet initiation conditions of a particular wire-electrode-based needleless electrospinning setup were determined at varying polymer type, solute concentration, and electrode geometries, which can be used for developing and validating the theoretical models for model-based intelligent nanofiber manufacturing. During this process, several rational synthesis routes of combining top-down electrospinning and bottom-up molecular/atomic self-assembly were formulated for first-time synthsis of several advanced hierarchally functionalized carbon nanofibers (CNFs) in the world. These advanced CNFs were demonstrated sucessfully for potential use as high-performance electrode materials in supercapacitors and pseduocapacitors such as graphene-beaded CNFs, ternary CNFs surface-grown with carbon-nanotubes (CNTs) and nanosized polyaninline, etc. Last Modified: 11/14/2016 Submitted by: Xiangfa Wu
